After watching this multiple times, I feel like the "slope has to be greater than one to trap the cobweb" wasn't comprehensively explained why it couldn't trap it, he only ever showed what happened if it gets beyond that point and never what happened if it is between the two intersections, so I only just understood why it doesn't get trapped at an intersection with slope greater than 1.

If the starting x value is exactly on an intersection of the line y=x (and I do mean EXACTLY) it works just fine regardless of slope: by definition, the output equals the input. The problem is that the cobweb cannot reach an intersection if its slope is greater than 1.

If the cobweb starts between the two intersections (Or more generally if x starts at a value where the function returns a value less than y=x) then the cobweb will actually go DOWN the line y=x, until it eventually settles into an intersection with slope less than 1 if such an intersection exists, or blows up to negative infinity if no such intersection exists, like for a regular old y=mx+b



PS: I know that grant says "it walks away from an intersection with slope greater than 1", but because he only showed an example from the side bigger than the intersection I just thought "well duh, of course if you start past all intersections it blows up, why didn't you show a point between them?"
I personally feel like showing a starting value on both sides would have made this much clearer

When you showed how multiplication is repeated addition, etc, etc, I feel there's a first step missing.

It might just be me, but I look at addition as repeatedly applying the successor operation to a number, which I think is important because the successor operation can be seen as the elementary arithmetic operation (being defined in the Peano axioms). In this way the step from exponentiation to tetration also is in fact the fourth step (I guess we could call the successor operation the 0th operation in this sense).

Something else I noticed which I found interesting, is that when looking at the cobweb converging to 2 when b equals sqrt(2), the point where b to the x intersects the line y = x *again*, going above it again, is in fact at (4,4), which does explain the fact that when you make the faulty assumption that the infinite power tower of x's can converge to 4, you will also end up with sqrt(2) as the solution for x.

@22:44 first I love the visualization here. What you are actually considering is convergence properties as it relates to fixed points. Fixed points are points on a function where the input maps to same output. Fixed points are a really cool piece of math that are incredibly important to an incredibly large number of areas in math. They are not something that is normally covered at the k12 level or even in early calculus classes though they definitely should be particularly in calc 2. These become highly important in advanced math. Arguably one of the most beautiful proofs in mathematics was the first proof of the Brouwer Fixed Point Theorem, which, among showing this for any convex and compact subset of a Banach space (all Euclidean spaces are notably part of this set) , showed that any continuous mapping of the closed unit disk to itself has at least 1 fixed point.

@19:21 to be explicitly clear about the error in logic here. Something happened that doesn’t normally happen when we’re dealing with normal equations. You don’t normally plug an equation into itself in order to solve it. Most of the time, this will just result in something like 0 = 0, but, in this case, we did do that. The mistake is really subtle, but, by plugging an equation into itself you have just assumed that the equation has a solution. If it were to have no solution then we can simply think of the equation itself being invalid since there is no value for which it is true, so plugging it into itself in cases where there is no solution will result in a concrete answer since you just assumed that the equation had to have one, but since the logic is circular it does not prove that that answer is actually correct. Notice how we also ignored the negative solution that spits out of our logic. This solution quite obviously doesn’t solve our equation considering that we are taking decimal powers of a negative number, but it comes out anyway since we assumed the equation converges. What you have, however, is something really useful which is the conditional statement that if the equation does converge for the value that our logic spits out then the resulting answer is a solution.

Just a tip for fixing the problem with the iterative functions in Desmos: a while back, I implemented the cobweb diagram for the logistic map into Desmos, and I used a trick where I would create a list called F0 containing only the starting value. I would define a function f0(x) = f(x), and I created a new list F1 = join(F0,f0(F0). Then, I would create the function f1(x) = f0(f0(x)), and the list F2 = join(F1,f1(F1)), and then create the function f2(x) = f1(f1(x)), and the list F3 = join(F2,f2(F2)), and so on. This let me create a list of 2^n values with only 2n+1 lines. It works like a binary number, but each bit represents the function applied some power of 2 times. In my case, I only needed 19 lines for a list of 512 values :)

At your misconception at the end I was thinking: (-√2)^(-√2) has no real solutions. This reminded me of my approach to find real solutions to powers.
For instance by my calculations I can find this example for a real solution with a base of (-√2) and an exponent that is not real:
(-√2)^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i) = -2^((2π-3)/20π-15π/(ln⁡2)^2)

But start at the beginning:
Let's say we have the complex numbers w and z. If we consider all the possible solutions for w^z in the complex plain, under what conditions will the solution be real?
Here are variables: w,z∈C, r,φ,a,b∈R, n,k∈Z
And define w and z like this: w=r·e^(i·(φ+2nπ)) , z=a+b·i

By calculating w^z I find two options for real solution: The fist one is trivial: If w=0 then w^z is 0, which is real, for all complex numbers z. (But consider for z=0: 0^0 is an indeterminate form.)
The second option is this condition: b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ)=kπ
So if we find a combination for integers n and k with the given values of r,φ,a,b to satisfy this condition, the result will be a real number.

Here is a proof for conditions we knew already, but can be confirmed now:
Let's see what we will have if z is a real number. The condition goes down to this: z·(φ+2nπ)=kπ
If additionally w is a positive real number, we get 2zn=k. That means we can choose n=0 regardless of the value of z, and get k=0. So if the base is positive and the exponent is real, we will always have at least one real solution. (For example: In this consideration of all possible solutions, 4^(1/2) has two: +2 and -2)
If on the other hand w is a negative real number, we can solve for z: z=k/(2n+1). That means: If the base is negative, the result can only be real if the exponent is a rational number with an odd denominator. (For example (-8)^(2/3)=4)
This also means: A negative real number raised to the power of an irrational real number has definitely no real solutions whatsoever.

Now I want to find a complex number z, for which (-√2)^z is real. The condition ends up like this: b·ln⁡2=2π(k-a·(2n+1)). By playing around I find this example for z: z=1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i
Calculating (-√2)^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i) I find this real solution: -2^((2π-3)/20π-15π/(ln⁡2)^2).

Here are my calculations in detail:

w,z∈C, r,φ,a,b∈R, n,k∈Z
w=r·e^(i·(φ+2nπ))
z=a+b·i
w^z=(r·e^(i·(φ+2nπ)))^(a+b·i)
w^z=r^(a+b·i)·e^(i·(φ+2nπ)·(a+b·i))
w^z=r^a·r^(i·b)·e^((a·i-b)·(φ+2nπ))
w^z=r^a·e^(i·b·ln⁡r )·e^(i·a·(φ+2nπ)-b·(φ+2nπ))
w^z=r^a·e^(-b·(φ+2nπ))·e^(i·(b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ)))
w^z=r^a·e^(-b·(φ+2nπ))·(cos⁡(b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ))+i·sin⁡(b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ)))
Im⁡(w^z)=r^a·e^(-b·(φ+2nπ))·sin⁡(b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ))
Im⁡(w^z)=0
1.: r^a=0 ⇒ r=0 ⇒ w=0
2.: sin⁡(b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ))=0 ⇒ b·ln⁡r+a·(φ+2nπ)=kπ
z∈R: z·(φ+2nπ)=kπ
z∈R, w∈R+: z·2nπ=kπ ⇒ 2zn=k
z∈R, w∈R-: z·(π+2nπ)=kπ ⇒ z·(2n+1)π=kπ ⇒ z=k/(2n+1)

w=-√2 ⇒ r=√2, φ=π
b·ln⁡√2+a·(π+2nπ)=kπ
b·ln⁡√2+aπ·(2n+1)=kπ
2b·ln⁡√2+2aπ·(2n+1)=2kπ
b·ln⁡2=2π(k-a·(2n+1))
z=1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i
⇒ 3/ln⁡2·ln⁡2=2π(k-(1/5-3/10π)·(2n+1))
⇒ 3=2π(k-2n/5+6n/10π-1/5+3/10π)
⇒ 3=2kπ-4nπ/5+6n/5-2π/5+3/5
⇒ 15=(10k-4n-2)π+6n+3
(n=2) ⇒ 15=(10k-10)π+15
(k=1) ⇒ 15=15
(-√2)^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i)
=(√2·e^(i·(π+2nπ)))^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i)
=(√2)^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i)·(e^(iπ·(2n+1)))^(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i)
=(√2)^((2π-3)/10π)·(e^ln⁡√2)^(3/ln⁡2·i)·e^(iπ·(2n+1)·(1/5-3/10π+3/ln⁡2·i))
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·e^(i·(3·(1/2)·ln⁡2)/ln⁡2)·e^(iπ·(2n+1)·(1/5-3/10π))·e^(-π·(2n+1)·3/ln⁡2)
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·e^(-π·(2n+1)·3/ln⁡2)·e^(i·(3/2+π/5·(2n+1)-3/10·(2n+1)))
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·e^(-π·(2n+1)·3/ln⁡2)·e^(i·(3/2+2nπ/5+π/5-3n/5-3/10))
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·e^(-π·(2n+1)·3/ln⁡2)·e^(i·(((4n+2)π-6n+12)/10))
(n=2):=2^((2π-3)/20π)·e^(-15π/ln⁡2)·e^(i·π)
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·(2^(ln⁡e/ln⁡2))^(-15π/ln⁡2)·e^(i·π)
=2^((2π-3)/20π)·2^(-15π/(ln⁡2)^2)·e^(i·π)
=2^((2π-3)/20π-15π/(ln⁡2)^2)·e^(i·π)
=2^((2π-3)/20π-15π/(ln⁡2)^2)·(cos⁡π+i·sin⁡π)
=-2^((2π-3)/20π-15π/(ln⁡2)^2)

It's pretty interesting. Let E- denote the lim_inf of the stacked power sequence and E+ the lim_sup of the stacked power sequence. These are the only limit points of the sequence.
When 0 < x < 1/(e^e), E- is strictly less than E+, so the power tower does not converge, but instead has two limit points. For 1/(e^e) <= x <= e^(1/ e), E- = E+ and the power tower converges. For x greater than the e-th root of e, E- (and hence the tower power) is divergent.
E- and E+ are the solutions to the pair of functional equations x ^a(x) = b(x) , x^b(x) = a(x). (See Aequationes Mathematicae 16 (1977) 137--147.)

The lower bound for tetration converging is solved for as follows:
The graphs y = b^x and y = x must intersect, so b^x = x, and the slope of y = b^x at the intersection must be = to -1, so ln(b) * b^x = 1. Therefore we have the following:
ln(b) * x = -1 --> ln(b) = -1/x --> b = e^(-1/x) --> [e^(-1/x)]^x = x --> e^(-1) = x = 1/e,
so b = e^(-1/x) = e^[-1/(1/e)] = e^(-e).

To answer the opening question, just find the solution to
x = 2ˣ
Oh wait. There is no solution. Well, no real solution – if you graph y = x and y = 2ˣ, they never intersect. Even "∞" won't work, because when x is 'transfinite,' 2ˣ is one order higher than x.
I leave it to others to determine whether there are any complex solutions.

But the act of graphing those two functions raises another interesting side-point:
If x = aˣ is to be solved for x, where real a > 1, what is the largest a = a₀ for which there is a solution? Clearly 1 < a₀ < 2.
That value will of course, make the two lines tangent at the solution.

Let f(x) = exp(W(log(x))), where W(x) is the Lambert W function.

For a given number `n`, we have:

a = f(n); n = a^a
b = f(a); n = a^(b^b)
c = f(b); n = a^(b^(c^c))
d = f(c); n = a^(b^(c^(d^d)))

etc...

In this way, we represent `n` (which can be any real or complex number) as a tower of powers of real or complex numbers, as far as we want to.

Yay! Googology! I'm a few days late, so probably less than 3 people are going to read this, but i love googology. The thing with the cups and coins is very interesting. If you start with 2 coins in the first cup and there are n cups, then the maximum number of coins at the end is about f_ω(n-1)  or  n↑↑...↑↑2 with n-1 arrows. For the specific game starting with 1 coin in each cup and 6 cups, the maximum number of coins is 2↑↑2↑↑2¹⁴, which is obviously much more than 2010↑↑3. That is very fast-growing for such a simple game. But as numbers, those are tiny compared to other numbers in googology. If you want to get into googology, the easiest way is probably Bird's Array Notation (BAN). It is basically the same as Bowers' Exploding Array Function (BEAF), but it's well-defined. BEAF is only described, but it's explained much more clearly, so maybe check that out before reading the formal definition of BAN. After that, i'd recommend the Extensible E and the Fast-Growing Hierarchy (FGH). I really hope someone will be interested in googology after reading this, because the community is very small.

The powers of 2 have (very) roughly a number of digits 1/3 of the exponent. So 2^10 has 4 digits, 2^20 has 7, 2^30 has 10 digits, 2^65536 has 19729 which is very loosely roughly poorly approximate to 1/3 of 65000.

So 2 to the power of 2*10^20000, probably has, something resembling 10^6000 digits. Waaaay beyond whatever the Earth is capable of storing and way past the most recent Skewes' Number (e^727), but not quite close to a humble Googleplex, which dwarfs next to Graham's number.

Looking at the desmos, I realized that for when 0 < b < 1, it becomes unstable when the two graphs are perpendicular. So here's my work:
b^x = x

d/dx [b^x] = -1/(d/dx [x])
ln(b) b^x = -1
ln(b) x = -1 (substituted using initial definition of b^x)
ln b = -1/x
b = e^(-1/x)

(e^(-1/x))^x = x
e^-1 = x

And the minimum base before it becomes unstable is:
b = e^-e

The graphs of (-sqrt(2))^x and y=x obviously do intersect at x=2. So if we set b=-sqrt(2) and a0=2, the iterations will stay fixed at 2. But if we start the iterations with any other a0, then it doesn't necessarily mean that we'll arrive at a(n)=2 at some point in the iteration.

This is similar to the b=sqrt(2) solution of x^x^x^........=4. Starting with b=sqrt(2) and a0=4 makes the iterations stay at 4. But with any other starting a0, we never arrive at a(n)=4 at any point in the iteration.

To arrive at a(n)=4 by starting at a0=\=4, we have to close-in on 4, but the fact that the slope at 4 is greater than 1 doesn't allow us to get closer and closer to 4.

Maybe we can use a similar idea to explain why a(k)=(-sqrt(2))^(k-1) never closes-in to a(n)=2 when a0=/=2. I don't know much about the complex logarithm. It could be that the norm of the complex derivative of (-sqrt(2))^x is greater than 1 at x=2.

Here is a proof of the power-tower of root 2 is 2, not 4:

Let a_0 = sqrt(2) and a_(n+1) = sqrt(2) ^ (a_n), for all non-negative integers n.
We can easily prove that a_n < 2 by induction.

Obviously a_n > 1 for all n, thus the sequence is increasing with 2 as an upper bound.

So the limit L exists and L is no greater than 2.

Consider the equation sqrt(2) ^ L = L
L ln(sqrt(2)) = ln(L)
ln(L) / L = ln(sqrt(2))
The only solution no greater than 2 is L = 2.

Hi Grant,

Firstly, thank you for your wonderful videos, they truly make math come alive for me and help me see things that I missed in my earlier years.
Now in regard to someone's question about applications of tetration, there is actually a common link between tetration (in the iterated exponentiation sense) and actual scientific application in several fields through the Lambert W function.
An iterated exponentiation, when it converges, can be written in a closed form using the W function, and so we can also consider how we might write the W function in terms of the iterated exponentiation function.
The Lambert W function does find its way into the exact solution of several problems across science and engineering - a quick look at the Wikipedia page on this topic will reveal many of them, even including the study of epidemics.

As to what this might actually mean, it's a question that I keep revisiting at least once a year.

I was so excited to see you tackle this- the infinite power tower and its convergence was something I discovered that fascinated me even before I graduated from high school, and I have explored it off and on for years since then.
To the person who brought up inverses of tetration- not only are they relevant somewhere, but one in particular is needed to derive, in my opinion, the most elegant closed-form expression for the infinite power tower in its range of convergence. Which, by the way, is e^(-e) <= x <= e^(1/e). (For x^x^x^...) I may discuss that further if someone is interested!
Now for 0 < x < e^(-e) = 1/e^e, it instead collapses into a stable 2-cycle. That is, as the power tower of such a value grows, over time it bounces back and forth between the same two values forever. One problem I tried to tackle a while back, and got some interesting empirical results for but never actually solved, was to find closed-form expressions for those two branches. However the circle is no longer a unit circle because we aren’t evaluating when x**4=1. To prove this is a lot of work but for z**n=a where n is an integer, the solutions lie on a circle of radius |a| * 1/n. In our case a is 4 so modulus of a positive real number is itself, so the radius of our circle is 4**1/4 which we saw earlier is square root 2. Roots of unity also shows us that if a is real the first root will lie on the real axis. So our first root is square root 2. The inverse of tetration question is a good one. Unfortunately, tetration cannot be defined continuously in a unique or completely satisfactory way. Usually, tetration is only defined for integer heights, which means that the overwhelming majority of the time, no inverse will exist. It's sort of like how very few numbers are perfect squares, even fewer are perfect cubes, etc. But for tetration, these properties are far less common even than for exponentiation. And since there is no conventional continuous extension, there is no conventional analogy to root or logarithms as inverses of tetration.

Wikipedia gives a few fun notations for higher-order operations. In his popular math book published 1995, Rudy Rucker used the notation ⁿx = x^(x^(x^(...x^x))...) with n copies of x. He seems to be the person to first popularize the name "tetration" for this operation, first introduced by Goodstein in 1947, and he would read this notation "the nth tetration of x" (by analogy to "the nth power of x" for xⁿ). He also gives further notations, like ₙx for the nth pentation of x (defined recursively as above), xₙ for the nth hexation of x, and then using overlines for further iterations, like xⁿ̅ for heptation, ̅ⁿx for octation, etc. Past decation, Unicode is no longer capable of typesetting this, but TeX has no trouble.

Knuth notation is also shown, and that notation is far more practical. You have xn for x·n, x↑n for xⁿ, x↑↑n for ⁿx, etc. The biggest advantage of Knuth's notation (apart from being easier to type and read) is that it can be indexed. For instance, x↑¹²n means x↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑n. This is handy for writing down enormous numbers, like the intermediate terms used to define Graham's number.

But the best notation of all has to be the hyper operator. If we restrict x to natural numbers, then all of these various operations are just hyperoperations which can be defined recursively very easily as a unified whole and written using the same function H. Typical notations include a↑ⁿb = H(a,b,n) = Hₙ(a,b) = a[n]b. Defined as a function of two arguments, Hₙ can be called the nth hyperoperation. H₀ is the successor function (H₀(a,b,) = b+1), H₁ is addition (H₁(a,b) = a+b), H₂ is multiplication (H₂(a,b) = a·b), H₃ is exponentiation (H₃(a,b,) = a^b), H₄ is tetration, etc.

As Grant said, it is still a triangle (because we still have two inputs and one output). So why do we have only one inverse operation until multiplication, and two different ones starting from exponentiation? Just because that's the point where the operation is no longer commutative (the order on the two inputs matters). If multiplication was not commutative (which happens in other settings, see for example Grant's video about quaternions), it would have also two inverse operations: dividing on the left and dividing on the right.

Grant refers to some problems with raising -sqrt(2) to a power. This is what I think about it.

If you make a function [negative]^x it won't give you consistent results. Try it, (-5)^x is defined at one point - (0;1). And if you put in (-5)^n and play with a slider changing n values it will hop between some number and undefined results. We have a convection: a^x is defined for any x only if a > 0 (If a = 0 we have problems with negative x's and also x = 0). So you might already understand why it is the case.

A wonderful example of this ambiguity: (-8)^(1/3) is obviously -2. But 1/3 is just a number, so like any ratio is can be also written like that: 2/6. So now (-8)^(1/3) is (-8)^(2/6). So you square -8 and get 64. And the 6th root of 64 is 2. Wonderful 2 = -2. If you try and extract the 6th root of -8 first it is of course undefined. So when you work with negative numbers you can't raise them in non-integer values, unless you mean taking nth root by that.

Hey, Grant! I sent you a tweet at the end of the stream regarding the number you got at the end, but I felt I could elaborate more here.


That one is the infamous "third solution" to the equation x^2 = 2^x! In fact, equations of the type x^a = b^x can be analysed using the Lambert-W function; in particular, for 2^x = x^2, we have to do two separate analyses.


The first one happens when we consider x to be a positive number; in this case, we can take the square root on both sides and get x = (2^x)^(1/2), which is equivalent to x = (sqrt(2))^x, and this gives us the solutions 2 and 4.


The other one happens when we consider the negative solution, namely -x = (2^x)^(1/2); to solve this using the Lambert-W function, the easier way I know is to make the substitution x = -y, and then we have y = (sqrt(1/2))^y, for which we get another fixed-point solution which is the number you got at the end.

Here's a short Haskell script which people can tweak to play with:
seed = -2**(1/2)
crazy a = -(-(seed))**a
crazyNums = iterate crazy 1
Simply change the value of "seed" to whatever starting number you want, and the value of "crazy a" to be whatever function you want to iterate. Then, Haskell kindly generates an infinite list of numbers!

This guy:
converges (x:xs) = x-(head xs) == 0 || converges xs
is a function which checks if a sequence of the kind defined above converges.

I recommend you run "converges crazyNums" on a Haskell interpreter. If true, then try calling "crazyNums !! 1000000" to find the million-and-first term (which is, practically speaking, a pretty good guess for an approximation of the conjectured stable fixed point).
